Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Story: I was sitting in the living room, watching my granddaughter’s eyes light up as she prepared to share her big news with the family. My daughter had gathered everyone, and I could feel the anticipation in the air. This was one of those moments I cherished—being present, listening, and showing my family how much they meant to me. Just as my granddaughter began to speak, my phone buzzed. It was a message from Tom, my old friend. “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m drowning in screws and planks over here. These instructions make no sense.” I knew he’d been struggling since his wife left, and he rarely asked for help. I glanced at my family, all eyes on my granddaughter, and then at my phone, picturing Tom’s frustrated face. My heart tugged in two directions—one toward the laughter and warmth of my family, the other toward a friend in need. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing on me, unsure which part of myself I should honor in this moment.
